questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for an 18-month history of gradual enlargement of her fingertips and a 2-month history of a hoarse voice. She has had decreased appetite after a respiratory tract infection 3 months ago and an 8-kg (17.6-lb) weight loss during this period. The patient has never smoked. She was diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea 10 years ago and uses a CPAP mask at night. She retired from her job as an administrative assistant at a local college 5 years ago. She appears tired. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows increased convexity of the nail fold and painful swelling of the soft tissue of her fingers and ankles. There is no discoloration of her lips and oral mucosa. There is faint wheezing in the right upper lung field. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased activity of serum ADH can be caused by the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion, which most commonly occurs in patients with small cell lung cancer (SCLC). SCLC can manifest with weight loss, fatigue, hoarseness (in case of advanced tumor growth), and pulmonary osteoarthropathy. However, SCLC is typically localized in the central parts of the lung; wheezing in the right upper lung field more likely indicates a peripheral tumor. Moreover, in the absence of cough and a history of cigarette smoking, SCLC is very unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has lung adenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of lung cancer in nonsmoking women. As lung adenocarcinoma typically affects the peripheral parts of the lungs, it may lead to Horner syndrome, which manifests with miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis due to compression of the cervical sympathetic nerves by the tumor (Pancoast tumor). The patient's hoarseness suggests involvement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve (usually a sign of advanced tumor growth), which indicates a worse outcome.

The next step in management in this patient is a CT scan of the chest to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the tumor to plan further diagnostic steps (e.g., biopsy) and treatment.
Image Description:

Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased activity of serum ACE can be a sign of disease activity in patients with sarcoidosis, which may manifest with fatigue, weight loss, and nail clubbing due to chronic hypoxia. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of sarcoidosis, such as dry cough, dyspnea, and basal rales on pulmonary auscultation, as well as extrapulmonary features of this condition, such as peripheral lymphadenopathy and iridocyclitis, making a different diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Reticular opacities on chest x-ray can be a sign of pulmonary fibrosis in patients with interstitial lung disease (e.g., asbestosis) that may lead to fatigue, weight loss, and nail clubbing due to chronic hypoxia. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of pulmonary fibrosis, such as dry cough, dyspnea, and basal inspiratory crackles or rales on pulmonary auscultation. Moreover, the absence of risk factors (e.g., smoking, a history of asbestos exposure, or farm work) makes a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral cyanosis can be a sign of decreased peripheral perfusion (e.g., due to decreased cardiac output or Raynaud disease), which causes blue discoloration of the fingers and/or extremities. This patient has a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and is likely to have a malignant lung tumor, both of which can cause hypoxia and, as a result, cyanosis. However, although chronic hypoxia can cause nail clubbing, hypoxia-related clubbing is usually painless. Additionally, OSA and lung tumors cause central cyanosis, which results in bluish discoloration of lips and tongue, not the fingers and/or extremities.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypercalcemia can be caused by paraneoplastic production of PTHrP, which most commonly occurs in patients with squamous cell lung carcinoma (SCC). This patient has some features of SCC including hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, weight loss, fatigue, and hoarse voice (in case of advanced tumor growth). While SCC is typically localized in central airways, this patient presents with wheezing in the right-upper lung field, indicating that she has a tumor localized in peripheral parts of the lung. Moreover, in the absence of cough and a history of cigarette smoking, SCC is very unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's hoarseness, wheezing in the right upper lung, and constitutional symptoms (weight loss, fatigue) should raise suspicion for a Pancoast tumor. She has likely developed a paraneoplastic syndrome, as indicated by her hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (i.e., nail clubbing and painful joint swelling).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent, sharp pain in the left shoulder that radiates to his neck. During this time, he has also had difficulty lifting heavy objects with his left arm. He has not had any recent trauma. He has noticed uneven sweating, with less sweat on the left side of his face. He has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss during the past 3 months despite no change in appetite or level of activity. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, and atorvastatin. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not drink alcoholic beverages or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. When measured in dim light, the left pupil measures 3 mm and the right pupil 5 mm in diameter. There is drooping of the left eyelid. Muscle strength is 3/5 on abduction and flexion of the left shoulder. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wallenberg syndrome, which is most commonly caused by posterior inferior cerebellar artery or vertebral artery occlusion (due to atherosclerosis), can manifest with Horner syndrome. In addition, this patient's history of smoking and hypertension increases his risk of developing cerebrovascular syndromes. However, Wallenberg syndrome does not manifest with shoulder pain and weight loss; expected findings include dysphagia, dysphonia, decreased gag reflex, ataxia, and nystagmus.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) may manifest with weight loss and shoulder pain. In addition, in 20% of cases, PMR is associated with giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can occasionally result in ptosis (due to an isolated oculomotor nerve palsy). However, the pain seen in PMR is typically symmetrical and patients usually have muscle stiffness, especially in the morning. Moreover, patients with GCA and an oculomotor nerve palsy present with a dilated or normal-sized pupil, not miosis. Finally, patients with GCA typically have additional clinical features such as headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and/or loss of vision.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of weight loss, unilateral shoulder pain and decreased functionality, and Horner syndrome in this elderly patient with a history of heavy smoking suggests a Pancoast tumor, an apical lung carcinoma (usually a type of NSCLC such as bronchogenic adenocarcinoma) that involves the superior sulcus of the lungs. Most symptoms of a Pancoast tumor are attributed to the compression of the surrounding structures: compression of the brachial plexus causes shoulder pain, while compression of the cervical sympathetic nerves by the tumor results in Horner syndrome. The next step in management should be a CT scan of the chest to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the tumor in order to plan further diagnostic steps (e.g., biopsy) and treatment.

Other possible findings of Pancoast tumor include hoarseness (due to laryngeal nerve compression) and unilateral arm edema (due to brachiocephalic vein obstruction).
Image Description:

Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

D) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery dissection may manifest with unilateral miosis, ptosis, and neck pain. In addition, this patient's history of smoking and hypertension increases his risk of developing this condition. However, carotid artery dissection does not explain the anhidrosis, since the sympathetic fibers of the facial sweat glands are located on the external carotid artery. Moreover, this patient does not present with ischemic features (e.g., amaurosis fugax, findings of middle cerebral artery infarction), which are typically seen in this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Angle-closure glaucoma can manifest with mydriasis, leading to anisocoria. However, the affected eye is usually reddened and severely painful, and most patients experience headache and/or orbital pain. In addition, angle-closure glaucoma does not manifest with anhidrosis, ptosis, shoulder pain, and weight loss.

F) INCORRECT:

Neurosyphilis may cause miosis. However, miosis in neurosyphilis is typically bilateral. In addition, patients with neurosyphilis usually present with Argyll Robertson pupils: the pupils accommodate but do not react to direct or indirect light. Furthermore, neurosyphilis does not usually manifest with anhidrosis, ptosis, and shoulder pain.

G) INCORRECT:

One of the first symptoms to develop in myasthenia gravis (MG) is ptosis. However, MG typically causes weakness (predominantly of the proximal muscle groups) that worsens with exercise and improves with rest rather than shoulder pain. Furthermore, anhidrosis and anisocoria are not expected findings.
questions.hint: This patient's unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis are consistent with Horner syndrome.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with hypertension, insulin-requiring diabetes mellitus, end-stage kidney disease, and a distant history of cigarette smoking presents with new-onset pain in her right shoulder and weakness in her right hand that have progressed during the past 6 weeks. In addition, she has lost 15 pounds during the past 4 months.
Physical examination reveals a unilateral, right-sided ptosis with a pinpoint pupil of the right eye, as well as muscle atrophy, hand weakness, and numbness in the fourth and fifth fingers of the right hand. No facial plethora is noted. The patient has no pain on percussion of her neck or back.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis leads to renal insufficiency and can cause sensorimotor neuropathy but is not associated with the development of Horner syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Although myasthenia gravis can cause ptosis and muscle weakness, it is not associated with miosis (a component of Horner syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Although carotid artery dissection could progress to stroke and subsequently cause arm weakness, this event would likely occur more acutely than the gradual development of Horner syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Tumors of the superior pulmonary sulcus, also called Pancoast tumors, can cause a classic presentation by compressing against nerve structures as they pass through or near the thoracic inlet. Compression of the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots can cause pain and neurologic compromise of those nerves. In addition, interruption of the sympathetic nerve chain running to the head can result in Horner syndrome, which is characterized by unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis. Treatment of superior pulmonary sulcus tumors involves multidisciplinary care coordinated among a thoracic surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist.

Key learning point: The gradual development of arm weakness and Horner syndrome in an older patient with a history of cigarette smoking is most indicative of a diagnosis of a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Arm weakness and numbness in the fingers is more consistent with a dermatomal distribution than with a brainstem lesion.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 36-year-old woman was in a motor vehicle crash about 3 weeks ago and suffered a significant whiplash injury. She presents with residual anterior neck pain and left supraorbital pain. Last night, she developed acute-onset right-sided face and hand weakness, as well as some difficulty producing spontaneous speech.
On examination, the patient has ptosis and a constricted pupil on the left side but no anhidrosis. She also exhibits a right-sided central facial droop with right-sided upper-extremity weakness and Broca-type aphasia.
An electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm without axis deviation. CT of the head reveals a hypodensity in the left frontal region.
Damage to which of the following structures on the left side is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Internal carotid dissection resulting from an acute trauma may initially cause only neck pain and headache, often unilateral. As the artery becomes distended, interruption of the ascending sympathetics to the eye may occur, causing a partial Horner syndrome. Anhidrosis does not occur because the sympathetic innervation of the sweat glands follows the external (not internal) carotid artery. Local distention of the internal carotid artery can also cause isolated cranial-nerve palsies. Dissection can result in emboli and stroke, often days or weeks after the trauma.

Key learning point: A patient with ipsilateral partial Horner syndrome, aphasia, and contralateral weakness following neck trauma should be evaluated for carotid dissection.

B) INCORRECT:

External carotid artery injuries do not generally lead to stroke, as this artery supplies mainly the face rather than the brain itself.

C) INCORRECT:

Damage to the jugular vein would manifest as pulsatile tinnitus, edema, or even raised intracranial pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Dissection of the vertebral artery does not cause symptoms of, or reveal CT evidence of, a hemispheric stroke. Vertebral artery dissection with distal embolization may produce a posterior-circulation stroke with symptoms of brainstem or cerebellar injury, including dysarthria, dysphagia, dizziness, and diplopia.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the cavernous sinus may yield a partial Horner syndrome but would also have neurologic features specific to the sinus, such as diplopia, ocular paralysis (third, fourth, and sixth cranial-nerve palsy), and facial numbness (fifth cranial-nerve palsy).

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with a left-sided retro-orbital headache that began earlier this morning and has not responded to acetaminophen. He also reports mild neck pain on the left side and mentions that his left eye looks “funny.” He has a history of infrequent, mild, bilateral, featureless headaches but is otherwise healthy and does not smoke.
His vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, his left eyelid hangs slightly lower than the right, and his left pupil is smaller when examined in a darkened exam room; the eye is not injected. Neurologic examination, including visual acuity, is otherwise normal. Neck range of motion is normal, with no meningismus.
What is the most appropriate initial evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An episode of partial Horner syndrome with ipsilateral headache suggests a “spontaneous” extracranial carotid dissection, particularly if the patient has neck pain. Hematoma resulting in expansion of the vessel wall leads to dysfunction of the surrounding sympathetic plexus, located around the carotid bifurcation and proximal internal carotid artery.

Soft-tissue and vascular imaging of the neck is diagnostic, and it will also assess for uncommon but potentially associated arteriopathies or other dissections. CT of the brain is useful only when intracranial pathology is suspected, but CT angiography of the neck would be able to make a diagnosis of dissection similar to that of magnetic resonance angiography.

Key learning point: An episode of new, partial Horner syndrome with ipsilateral headache in an otherwise healthy patient should be assumed to be a carotid dissection, until proven otherwise.

B) INCORRECT:

Horner syndrome is always due to damage to the sympathetic nervous system, so a slit-lamp examination of the eye examining the retina, anterior chamber, and optic nerve would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

A cluster headache may manifest as a Horner episode and usually responds to 100% oxygen, but the pattern is one of brief, recurring headaches.

D) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph could reveal a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor or a widened mediastinum of an aortic dissection, but it is not helpful for an acute presentation that is inconsistent with tumor. A chest radiograph will also not identify carotid dissections.

E) INCORRECT:

CT of the brain is useful only when intracranial pathology is suspected, but CT angiography of the neck would be able to make a diagnosis of dissection similar to that of magnetic resonance angiography.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife has noticed that his left eye looks smaller than his right. He has had worsening left shoulder and arm pain for 3 months. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows left-sided ptosis. The pupils are unequal but reactive to light; when measured in dim light, the left pupil is 3 mm and the right pupil is 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ophthalmologic symptoms?

choices.text: Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis can result in Horner syndrome due to compression of postganglionic sympathetic neurons. However, cavernous sinus thrombosis has additional symptoms that are not present in this case, such as headache, photophobia, proptosis, and other cranial nerve palsies (commonly CN VI). In addition, cavernous sinus thrombosis is most commonly caused by an ascending infection from the face or sinuses, signs of which are not present here. This patient's arm and shoulder pain would likewise not be explained by cavernous sinus thrombosis.
Image Description:

The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is completely surrounded by the cavernous sinus. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of the cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerve are located towards the lateral wall of the sinus.

B) INCORRECT:

Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery could compress CN III, which carries parasympathetic fibers to the pupillary sphincter and ciliary muscle, and motor fibers to the levator palpebrae superioris and all extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique muscle and the lateral rectus muscle. Such an aneurysm would result in ptosis, which this patient has, as well as diplopia, a fixed and dilated pupil, and a down-and-out gaze, which are not present here. Rather than mydriasis, this patient has miosis. Furthermore, if such an aneurysm were symptomatic, it would manifest with headache rather than the shoulder and arm pain seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the hypothalamus is a rare cause of Horner syndrome secondary to injury of centrally located sympathetic neurons. This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for stroke, including infarction of the hypothalamus. However, an infarction of the hypothalamus would likely manifest with additional stroke symptoms, typically contralateral hemiparesis and hypesthesia, as well as impeded homeostatic functions of the hypothalamus (e.g., thermoregulation, electrolyte balance, sleep-wake cycle). Furthermore, infarction of the hypothalamus would not explain this patient's shoulder and arm pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery dissection can cause Horner syndrome by compressing the postganglionic sympathetic fibers near the internal carotid artery and damaging them directly or decreasing blood flow to their vasa nervorum. This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for carotid artery dissection. However, carotid artery dissection most often has an acute onset of symptoms following some types of trauma (e.g., blunt trauma), which is not the case here. Furthermore, in addition to Horner syndrome, carotid artery dissection would manifest with headache and/or neck pain, while this patient has shoulder and arm pain.

E) CORRECT:

Compression of the stellate ganglion by a Pancoast tumor can lead to Horner syndrome via injury of preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Superior sulcus tumors can infiltrate neighboring structures and cause additional symptoms, which is known as Pancoast syndrome. This patient's shoulder and arm pain are likely symptoms of Pancoast syndrome, which also includes atrophy of the arm and hand muscles, and possibly superior vena cava syndrome and hoarseness due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The most common cause of Pancoast syndrome is NSCLC, for which this patient is at risk because of his history of smoking.
Image Description:

Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

F) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of the cervical plexus, typically by neck soft tissue tumors or lymph node metastases, manifests with pain in the neck and submandibular area, as well as sensory loss in the C2, C3, and C4 dermatomes, symptoms which this patient does not have. It would not be expected to cause Horner syndrome or shoulder and arm pain.
questions.hint: Horner syndrome (HS) is a neurological disorder characterized by a symptom triad of miosis, partial ptosis, and facial anhidrosis, of which this patient has the former two symptoms. In a heavy smoker, symptoms of Horner syndrome combined with ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain are concerning for a Pancoast tumor.
